2000.title: The Concorde has crashed killing all 109 aboard
2000.description: Concorde Air France Flight 4590 crashes just after takeoff from Paris killing all 109 aboard and 5 on the ground.

2000.title: The Martin County coal slurry spill
2000.description: The Martin County coal slurry spill was a mining accident that occurred after midnight on October 11, 2000, an estimated 306 million US gallons of 'Black Sluge' oil slurry containing arsenic and mercury was released into the river. The spill is 30 times larger then Exxon Valdez and polluted 200-300 miles of land

2002.title: C02 ihn the atmosphere has passed 400ppm

2003.title: C02 ihn the atmosphere has passed 400ppm

2011.title: Western Black Rhino.
2011.description: The rarest of the black rhino subspecies, the Western black rhino (Diceros bicornis ssp. longipes) was recognized by the IUCN as extinct in 2011 The species was once widespread in central Africa, but the population began a steep decline due to poaching.

2010.title: The Deepwater Horizon oil spill.
2010.description: On April 20, 2010, the oil drilling rig Deepwater Horizon, operating in the Macondo Prospect in the Gulf of Mexico, exploded and sank resulting in the death of 11 workers on the Deepwater Horizon and the largest spill of oil in the history of marine oil drilling operations.  4 million barrels of oil flowed from the damaged Macondo well over an 87-day period, before it was finally capped on July 15, 2010.

2013.title: Peak Coal
2013.description: Peak coal is the peak consumption or production of coal by a human community. Global coal consumption peaked in 2013, and had dropped slightly by the end of the 2010s.

2013.title: Extinction of Chioninia coctei
2013.description: The Chioninia cocteri was a species of lizard that was once found in the islets of Branco and Raso in Cape Verde. It was declared extinct in 2013.

2015.title: 400ppm CO2 average
2015.description: The first time we have bypassed 400ppm of C02 concentration in the atmosphere

2016.title: BrexitVote
2016.description: The withdrawal of the United Kingdom (UK) from the European Union (EU) at 23:00 GMT on 31 January 2020

2019.title: The Spix's macaw is declared extinct
2019.description: TThe Spix's macaw (Cyanopsitta spixii), endemic to Brazil, was last seen in the wild in 2016.6 It was declared extinct in the wild in 2019, but there are currently around 160 of these parrots in captivity.

2020.title: 421ppm CO2 average
2020.description: The average CO2 concentration in the atmosphere

2021.title: 47% of humans live in water scarsity
2021.description: almost half of all humans live in areas that suffer water scarcity at least 1 month each year.

2022.title: Extinction of Mountain Mist Frog
2022.description: The Mountain Mist Frog (Ranoidea nyakalensis) was a species of frog that was endemic to Australia. It was declared extinct in 2022.

2023.title: 8,031,800,338 humans on earth
2023.description: According to the UN, about two-thirds of the predicted growth in population between 2020 and 2050 will take place in Africa.

2028.title: Peak Oil
2028.description: Shale reserves are predicted to peak before 2030

2030.title: Peak Phosphorus
2030.description: Earth's commercial and affordable phosphorus reserves are expected to be depleted in 50–100 years and peak phosphorus to be reached in approximately 2030.

2040.title: the world's economy will begin to lose ground
2040.description: The two scenarios aligning most closely with observed data indicate a halt in welfare, food, and industrial production over the next decade or so, which puts into question the suitability of continuous economic growth as humanity's goal in the twenty-first century.

2048.title: Fish have been depleated from the ocean
2048.description: Human-dominated marine ecosystems are experiencing accelerating loss of populations and species, with largely unknown consequences.

2049.title: More Plastic then Fish
2049.description: Starting with an estimate that 150 million tonnes of plastic are already polluting the world's oceans, and that "leakage" adds at least 9.1 million tonnes more each year — a figure that is said to be growing by five per cent annually — the MacArthur report calculates there will be 850-950 million tonnes of ocean plastic by 2050, versus total fish stocks of 812-899 million tonnes.
